newsitem.title: USA: Cheung Labs treatment ability confirmed.
newsitem.headline: Cheung Labs treatment ability confirmed.

text.p: Cheung Laboratories Inc Wednesday said a study at the Massachusetts General Hospital's Center for Imaging and Pharmaceutical Research confirmed the ability of Cheung's breast cancer treatment to target and effectively heat a desired area within a live animal.

In this research, in vivo studies using animal tumors were used to evaluate the Cheung system's ability to target tumors with "deep focused heat" generated with microwave antennae located outside the body, the company said.
Cheung Labs said it plans to conduct clinical trials of focused heat and either chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
These tests will be at multiple hospital sites to obtain safety and efficacy data towards gaining U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval for commercialization of the system.

Its statment quoted Dr. Gerald L. Wolf, director of the center, as saying "This device can give me the kind of focused treatment I need in regimens intended to eradicate localized tumors. It's one of the front-running candidates for eliminating localized tumors while being minimally invasive."

The system uses Adapted Phased Array (APA) technology developed by Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which originally was used in microwave radar guidance systems for "Star Wars" defense systems by the U.S. Department of Defense.
Cheung Labs said it has an exclusive license agreement with MIT for commercialization of APA technology.
